context:
On a related note:

Import tariffs introduced by President Donald Trump aimed at protecting American manufacturers have actually caused job losses and higher prices for consumers, according to a study published by the U.S. Federal Reserve.

In March 2018, the Trump administration introduced steel and aluminum tariffs to counter what the president described as "aggressive foreign trade practices."

The president also took aim at Chinese goods as he started a trade war with Beijing that may be soon eased with a preliminary trade deal.

However, Federal Reserve economists Aaron Flaaen and Justin Pierce concluded that any gains made by the tariffs in reducing competition for some U.S. domestic industries were cancelled out by rising input costs and retaliatory tariffs.


NO ONE, including Trump, has dealt well with China since Nixon.

replies.context: Wrong.  I am in sales and have been selling Asian products in the US for 30+ years.  The tariffs are causing US manufacturers to move their contract manufacturing and component sourcing to other countries and in many cases to the US.  Tariffs are working and if we have to pay more for products typically coming from China, so what.  The Chinese government is not our friend, and it is the first time in 30+ years our government has sent Beijing a wake up call.

See, you are thinking logically and realistically, unlike the misnamed individual you are responding to.  Tariffs cause short term pain to the citizens of the countries where the tariffs originate - but long-term gain for the same citizens, while causing pain - short term AND long term to the businesses and nations being targetted by those same tariffs.  Right now, Americans pay a bit more for Chinese-originated products.  But as companies realize the cost of doing business in China, they move out to more 'tariff-friendly' locations/nations and then the cost goes back down for Americans, and they also have some better security.  But for the Chinese, a) they sell less products to America, b) companies leave their shores for better places and thereby cost the Chinese jobs, c) which raise the costs to care for their own now-unemployed citizens.  And considering that China, in spite of all they've done, are sitting on some static or stagnant economic numbers, this is hitting China much harder than it is America.  And if these companies move from China to America, then more Americans get employed, taking away the jobs from Chinese employees, and also costing the Chinese officials their percentage of the grift they charge foreign companies to exist in China.  Win, win, win, for America; lose, lose, lose for China.
Hard to see how manufacturing something in America causes US job losses versus manufacturing the same thing in China.

The science of product assembly (i.e. manufacturing) has advanced to minimize human input.  Products are designed so they can only be assembled in a single (correct) way, integrated statistical process control schemes flag abnormal conditions, vision systems use bar codes to ensure the correct components are being used, etc.

The simple fact is that these multi-million dollar investments, made to improve first time quality (FTQ), are BENEFICIAL to society.  

Our challenge is disguised as manufacturing, but the real problem is elevating the skill level of our least skilled people.

context: Now address all the tech companies using foreign technicians. We have more foreigners running our tech in big corporations than US citizens. Where do their loyalties lie?

How many Chinese-made “drones” have been sold in the U.S.? Maybe several hundred thousand, used by people like me and others who enjoy radio-controlled models of cars, airplanes, etc. Most of us have more than one, so that reduces the actual number being used at any given time.

 The much, much larger number of Chinese-made devices that can (and do) collect data is truly scary if you think about it...

 Just about everything that is considered a “smart” device, from our cell phones, laptops, PC’s, and things like Amazon’s “Alexa” and Google’s “Echo” and even “Ring” type doorbell cameras is made in China. You can bet everything you use them for is being recorded by something and/or somebody over in China. Think about it - they have 400 bazillion people over there with not much to do. Of course they’re watching us! They know when we go to work and come home, they know what we buy from the grocery store, and yes, they know when we’re playing “hide the salami” in our bedrooms, and they’re probably laughing at us as they watch.

 It’s just a matter of time before they attack. They’re just waiting for the perfect time.

I hardly think DJI practices predatory pricing: I paid close to $1000 for the unit I purchased three years ago. It works very well, easy to operate, and takes great video. If the Chinese want GPS coordinates for critical infrastructure, they can use Google Maps or take anything with a GPS receiver, drive around, and record coordinates on paper. A drone is overkill.

The real problem is that we outsourced all our manufacturing to China. You can fill up a device with Intel, Micron, Cisco, you-name-it parts and devices and it's still sourced from China. Not only does China possess manufacturing capability, it also possesses the intellectual property used to make the parts. They also have a lot of smart people able to reverse-engineer the designs and modify them as they wish and we pretty much gave the store away filling up our universities with full-fare paying Chinese students. I'd hate to know what they say about us when we're not listening (Mandarin for "suckers"?).

While kids in other countries are expected to learn math, science, and appreciation of their culture (warts and all), we spend billions teaching them junk science, feelings, and that they should despise their heritage.

Drones are the least of our worries - it's picking at nits.

Too little too late. The US military, law enforcement, Border patrol, etc have a much bigger problem than drones.  These agencies have been buying and using Chinese networking elements for years.  The devices are embedded in the most sensitive locations throughout our government.  Now, all of a sudden, there is a sense of urgency about drone.  Nonsense, look at all of your routers and switches with the govnerments networks that have Chinese sniffing components embedded in them.  You got bigger problems than drones.

Building our own drones is not difficult. You can still use parts from china. The problem is related to firmware. The programming code that instructs the microprocessors in the drones what to do with the data it collects. That is all it is. Drones can be built pretty easily that can rival DJI drones with better secured firmware.

context: Everything on Chinese drones are safely usable except the radio and control unit. Should NOT be that hard to make those components here.

Any drone that uses your phone/tablet for video or control is potentially a security threat. Existing drones that use their own controller with built in display (like Yuneec Typhoon H and Q500) and are never connected to the world outside via cell or external wifi are much less of a security risk.

However, with the FAA's proposed new rules, all new drones will be required to be continually connected to the outside world via cell or wifi. The problem will get worse.
